awd_titl_txt: US-Liberia Workshop on Engineering Leadership; Monrovia, Liberia; 13-26 August 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This award, co-funded by the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation and the Division of Engineering Education and Centers, supports travel for members of the Society of Women Engineers at the University of Michigan to travel to Monrovia, Liberia in August 2019 for a workshop and training program for rising female engineering leaders. The University of Michigan team members represent Mechanical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Civil and Environmental Engineering, the School for the Environment and Sustainability, and Materials Science Engineering. This workshop provides an unprecedented educational, training and mentoring opportunity for Engineering students to work with peers from an African university, with the objective of Broadening Participation in Civil Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Manufacturing Research. 

The University of Michigan student group will partner with the Liberia Society of Women Engineers  student organization for an Engineering leadership camp for 40 female STEM students. The goals of this camp are two-fold (i) to empower the US and Liberian women engineers with the skills, support, and inspiration necessary to becoming successful and well- rounded engineering professionals; and (ii) to strengthen the community of female engineers in the US and Liberia by building cross-cultural partnerships among female engineering students, resulting in a global network of women engineers. The undergraduate students will participate in workshops led by Engineering graduate students which will include an overview of the graduate school application process, GRE preparation, proposal writing, resume building, networking skills, and hands-on engineering projects focused on Civil and Mechanical Engineering.  Additionally, the US and Liberian undergraduate students will lead workshops on student organization development and STEM outreach in order to strengthen their organization and provide strategies for persisting and thriving as part of underrepresented minority groups in engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project are to provide the UM-SWE members with an unprecedented mentoring and networking opportunity with undergraduate peers from an African university, along with an enriching cultural exchange. The UM team members are responsible for developing the curriculum and leading workshops and engineering modules for all participants. 

The specific objectives were to provide the following skills to Liberian students:

1. Career development for industry positions/networking skills

2. Graduate school applications

3. Leadership and conflict management skills

Furthermore, this program gives insights into the impacts of student organizations on student learning in African countries, especially in contexts void of role models and mentors. It provides an opportunity to study the experiences of female engineering students in an all-female environment. 

The workshop was well attended with 24 students. It allowed for intermingling of US and Liberian students with the goal of creating long-term professional relationships. This type of professional development workshop is non existent at the University of Liberia. By providing such access, female engineering students, typically disadvantaged in the local networking environment, are given a chance to level the playing field. 

The ultimate goal is to increase the number of female engineers on the African continent. The average age in Africa is far below that of Europe or North America. Africa is the future and it is essential that our US students understand the culture on the continent and are able to create long lasting meaningful and professional relationships with their African peers. 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Aline Cotel
